comments.commentBody: to MontréalMoe: The one thing, of many, that I love about my American neighbours, when they disagree with you, it's never personalized & it never dissolves into a character assassination attempt however, when Canadians argue their point, they throw everything at you assuming if one thing doesn't make a dent, the other 29 will. After tearing a page from the American how-to manual on leadership etiquette, the main reason PM Harper visited Slave Lake was due in large part to the dearth of original ideas that circulate in his cerebellum; he seized the auspicious opportunity prior to his flight to Deauville. It's in his DNA; for example: lest we forget, as leader of the Opposition, the speech he delivered to Parliament on March 20, 2003, where he outlined his position on his support for the invasion of Iraq which was eerily lifted from the speech Australian PM Howard delivered two days earlier ... oops!

I don't know whether this particular disaster had anything to do with global warming, but I do know the salient and immediate effect of global warming in the present is, in the recent past was, and for some time in the future will be, extreme weather. The corporate interests say we can't afford to address global warming, and yet every year the effects of global warming costs us millions and millions (as Carl Sagan would not have put it) of dollars, and every year it gets worse. From an economic standpoint alone, we can't NOT afford to address global warming.

This is like, I suppose, the frequent bloody shooting rampages we have in this country--in that afterward we aren't allowed to breath the phrase "gun control". Whenever extreme weather destroys whole cities and kills hundreds and thousands nowadays (it seems to happen every other week or so), we aren't allowed even to breath the phrase "global warming".

Well, *I'm* saying it, but I don't hear any politicians saying it (a fortiori actually doing anything about it), and I don't hear any reporters or columnists saying it.

for an individual person affected by it, each tragedy and each disaster (whether natural or man-made) stands on its own and defies comparison. But we must also put things in perspective by aggregating it in total.

The magnitude of total destruction wrought by the 2011 tornado season in the US pales in comparison to that by the 2011 earthquake and tsunami of Japan, in every category and classification. By the same token, the magnitude of total recovery required from the tornadoes also pales in comparison to that from the earthquake & tsunami.

If the people of Japan can respond to the destruction with matching order, stoicism, resilience and reconstruction, so can we. And without regard to whether a sitting President shows up or not or how fast the central government orchestrates disaster relief.

I have been working very slowly and carefully on a book about Michelangelo for quite a few years that has involved looking at every extant work by the artist. I have closely studied the Gardner pietà drawing but have not seen the Kober painting. I would never dare, based on images on a Web site, speculate whether this is in Michelangelo's hand. But I would like to address things raised by other commenters as well as raise points on my own. First, M. did many "presentation drawings" for Vittoria Colonna, whom he loved dearly as a friend. These are not "sketches" as some have said, but finished works of art he presented to her. That is a world of difference. There are several sublime presentation drawings that M did for Vittoria --all on religious themes- in the Queen's private collection at Windsor Castle. The Gardner drawing, akin to those at Windsor, shows his values and skills from about 1532 (when he was 57) to about 1555 (when he was 80). His style certainly evolved, became in some ways more essential and austere. A "translation" into paint, whether done by M, by a contemporary, or later on, would perforce be different because it is a different medium. So to would sculpture, for all the obvious reasons. Then, this is hardly the first Michelangelo to be "discovered" in modern times. There was a painting found, I believe, in Scotland that was restored at the Met museum and then the Met allowed itself to be outbid by the Kimbell Museum in Ft. Worth--final price about $76 million, I think. A real failure on the Met's part when it had spent more on paintings of less value or heritage. Allan in Torino mentioned a wood cross "found" in Italy. There were actually two. The most recent is of uncertain authorship but the one before (in Florence) was not.    Some commenters said the Kober is crudely painted. I invite you to look at the Manchester Madonna and the Deposition, both paintings by M at London's National Gallery. Both are glorious but one could also find a crudeness to them. Michelangelo was Mannerist and some of his painting is closer in style to El Greco (who met M in Rome) than to gorgeous figures by Bellini, Botticelli or other artists slightly older than M. I enjoyed the spirit of the words of commenter #25. And I was engaged by the commenter who wrote that Michelangelo never set his paintings at night. I would have to think further on that. Certainly there is darkness is some of the scenes of The Last Judgment on the wall (not ceiling) of the Sistine Chapel, which dates to about 1545.   There is a painting he did of Leda and the Swan for the Duke of Ferrara which is now thought to be lost (it belonged to Francis I of France but went missing). It is in closeup detail --according to the copies made by other artists at the time-- with a dark background that does not connote daylight. Then there is the Medici Chapel in Florence, where the sculptures evoke Night and Day, Dawn and Dusk. Like Beethoven, Shakespeare, Mozart and just a few other creators, Michelangelo is larger, more complex and universal than any one of us can describe. So we look at him in pieces, closely and repeatedly if we are fortunate to do so, and accept that the questions are at least as thrilling as the answers.
